Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, the unopened envelope from work heavy in my hands. My son’s excited voice echoed from the living room, reminding me of the promise I’d made weeks ago: a Nintendo for his birthday. He’d been counting down the days, his eyes shining with hope every time he mentioned it. As a mother, I wanted to give him everything, to see him happy and to keep my promise. But the numbers in my bank account told a different story. We were barely making ends meet, and I knew that buying the Nintendo would mean cutting back on groceries or skipping a bill.

At the same time, my faith pressed on my conscience. As a Christian, I tried to live simply, to avoid material excess, and to teach my son the value of gratitude and contentment. Was I teaching him to want more than he needed? Was I putting worldly happiness above spiritual lessons? The pressure from both sides squeezed my heart. I wanted to be a good mother, but I also wanted to be true to my beliefs. I stared at the envelope, torn between the joy in my son’s eyes and the quiet voice of my faith, unsure which path to take.
